title: CSS Tables
subject: CSS
theory:
CSS greatly improves the look of HTML tables.

*   `border`: Specifies borders for tables, rows, and cells.
*   `border-collapse`: Whether table borders should be collapsed into a single border or detached.
*   `text-align` & `vertical-align`: Aligns text within cells.
*   `padding`: Adds space inside cells.

examples.output: Every even row has a grey background.
examples.explanation: Creates a 'Zebra Striped' table for better readability of large datasets.

common_mistakes.correction: By default, tables have separate borders for the table and cells. Use `border-collapse: collapse` to fix this.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between border-collapse: separate and collapse?
interview_questions.answer: Separate (default) keeps space between cell borders. Collapse merges them into one single border.

practice_problems.problem: Center text in all table headers <th>.

real_world_use_cases.description: Financial and Admin dashboards rely heavily on clean, well-spaced, striped tables to present data.

exam_notes: border-spacing only works when border-collapse is separate.
caption-side puts the table caption top or bottom.
summary: While not used for layout anymore, tables are essential for data. CSS makes them readable and beautiful.
